item.title: 30th International Seminar on Economic Policy
item.description: I’m on the organising committee of the 30th International Seminar on Economic Policy (SIPE), the 13th and 14th of September, 2018. SIPE is an annual event at the Department of Agricultural Economics, UFV. Fot the 30th anniversary, the event will be especially great, with the main theme being “Sustainability and Perspectives for the Brazilian Agriculture”. Certainly, there will be much interesting discussion around the latest Brazilian agricultural census that has just been released, and plenty of other interesting topics related to the future of Brazilian agriculture.

item.title: A Multidimensional Failure
item.description: When doing research – venturing into the great unknown – one does not always know if one’s ideas will work out or not. I think it is inevitable that one spends time pursuing and nurturing some idea that, in the very end, turns out not to be so good. Or downright terrible, in some cases. Although some may not find this kind of thing worthy to discuss, maybe a small note here could help some other researcher avoid wasting their precious time and coming to the same dead end. So here’s a little story of my failed idea.

item.title: SDP+QC: A Short Progress Report
item.description:
The research project on quantum computing and stochastic dynamic optimisation is just hitting its stride, and we’re getting closer to showing some very exciting results!

The project is well underway – about halfway through its planned course – so it’s about time to take stock and see where this is going.

item.title: Reinforcements are Coming!
item.description: As part of my research project on stochastic dynamic programming and quantum computing, I find myself having to do a lot of heavy calculations lately. Waiting anxiously for a long time for a new set of results (or waiting to find out that the calculation just failed spectacularly) is one of the least enjoyable aspects of this kind of research. In an attempt to reduce this to a minimum, I decided to splash out on a brand new workstation – hopefully it will make me a much more productive and efficient researcher!

item.title: Stochastic Dynamic Optimisation Reading List
item.description: As part of my project on stochastic dynamic optimisation, I am knee-deep in good literature on the subject. So here is some literature that I recommend for getting acquainted with the subject. Some are research articles of particular note, and some are textbooks – but they should all be accessible to someone at an advanced undergraduate level and above.

item.title: Workshop on Stochastic Dynamic Optimisation
item.description: As part of my research project on quantum computing and stochastic dynamic optimisation, I have invited a small number of researchers to a workshop to talk about stochastic dynamic optimisation. If anybody reading this would like to join the workshop, please don’t hesitate to reach out. If two heads are better than one, then just imagine how great a roomful of research scientists must be!

item.title: Testing the Julia Programming Language
item.description:
I have been hearing a lot about the Julia programming language lately. And what I’ve been hearing is basically that it is “(nearly) as fast as C/C++” and “as easy as Python”. Since my research relies heavily on computations, I thought it might be good to try using it in my project on stochastic dynamic optimisation.

Does it fit the bill?

item.title: Serrapilheira Event in Rio
item.description: Instituto Serrapilheira has invited all their grantees from their first call to an event in Rio de Janeira this week. It is a great opportunity to meet young, talented scientists from all over Brazil. The Instituto Serrapilheira has very generously sponsored my project about stochastic dynamic optimisation, and I’m looking forward to finally meeting the people behind it. Not only does the institute fund scientific research projects, but I really like their focus on both diversity and open science – values that personally appeal to me.

item.title: Two Incredibly Useful Taylor Expansions
item.description: A “Taylor expansions” is a polynomial that approximates a function in a small vicinity of a single point. They are exceptionally useful: in general, we are pretty good at solving problems involving polynomials and pretty rubbish at solving problems involving pretty much anything else. Here, we show you two elegant Taylor expansions that keep showing up here and there in different areas of research.

item.title: Everything is a Stochastic Dynamic Optimisation Problem!
item.description: Stochastic dynamic optimisation problems are everywhere – quite simply because most of the choices we make have consequences in the future, and incorporate some uncertainty: this means that the decision process needs to take into account not only whatever happens at the moment that the decision is made, but also how it may impact future decisions. These are common characteristics of real-world problems – and all such problems present a great opportunity to study the art and science of stochastic dynamic optimisation!

item.title: The rule of 72
item.description:
The “rule of 72” is – or at least should be – a standard tool in everyone’s mathematical toolkit, and helps us think intuitively about exponential growth and exponential decay.

But did you ever stop and wonder how and why this black magic incantation actually works?

item.title: My Phd Thesis Won an Award
item.description: On wednesday last week, the winners of the awards (one per field) for best PhD theses in Brazil in 2016 were announced. And, lo and behold, there was my name in the official gazette – receiving the award in the field of economics for my thesis on energy and climate change.
